image.altText: A huge cylindrical structure with US-style stars and stripes painted on one end is seen at an ourdoor facility, with people.

items.synopsis: Two years since the AUKUS deal, some American politicians are calling for the US to step up its shipbuilding before selling subs to Australia, while others say Donald Trump's possible return to power means congress should move more quickly.

title.children: Prospect of another 'erratic' Trump presidency prompts call to move faster on AUKUS

image.altText: Hugh Jackman, right., and Deborra-Lee Furness Jackman attend a movie premiere.

items.synopsis: The couple release a statement confirming their split after 27 years of marriage, saying they have decided to "pursue individual growth".

title.children: 'Our journey now is shifting': Hugh Jackman and Deborra-Lee Furness announce separation

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing a black hoodie with the "yes" logo on the front.

items.synopsis: There are another four weeks until Australians will officially cast their votes in the first referendum in more than two decades. For the Yes campaign, there is a path to success, albeit a narrow one, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: The comments that reveal just how clearly the No campaign is leading the Voice debate

image.altText: Queen Silvia dressed in a white gown and King Carl XVI Gustaf wearing a dark suit walk together in front of a guard.

items.synopsis: As some global royals come under the microscope for their role in modern society, it seems Sweden's king is more popular than ever, despite a scandal-plagued reign.

title.children: Mafia links, sex parties and the modern monarchy that's more popular than ever

image.altText: A map of the world with Australia at the fore and different coloured bands showing airmasses

items.synopsis: It's already feeling like summer. Temperatures in central and south-eastern Australia have climbed to 10 degrees Celsius above average and more hot weather is on the way.

title.children: Just two weeks out of winter and it's already feeling like summer. Here's why

image.altText: A man in a yellow shirt and dirty face on a computer with other men on computers around him.

items.synopsis: China is working with neighbouring countries to crack down on the scam operations that are plaguing the region — including Australia.

title.children: Will China's scam crackdown have an effect in Australia?

image.altText: The Aussie dollar is a painful dollar for Nai and her children.

items.synopsis: A near-record number of Pacific Islanders are in Australia working on farms and abattoirs. The workforce has kept Australia's agricultural economy afloat and transformed the lives of thousands — but it comes at a cost.

title.children: The Aussie dollar is a painful dollar — Nai and her children feel it everyday

image.altText: Row of black and red Teslas in a parking lot.

items.synopsis: A major car rental company was renting Teslas out for about one-third the cost of a petrol car. We figured, how different could it be?

title.children: I rented a Tesla for a month. It was a giant pain in the a***

image.altText: A man with grey hair and moustache, wearing yellow firefighter overalls, stands with a young smiling woman.

items.synopsis: The stereotypical image of a climate activist is a young radical, but now older, formerly law-abiding citizens are joining the fight — on the ground and through the courts.

title.children: After 40 years fighting fires, Alan risked jail to join young climate activists like Violet. He's not alone and here's why

image.altText: Man in suit points to chalkboard.

items.synopsis: When Robert Goddard thought he'd figured out how to get humans into space in 1920, the press called his ideas "absurd". Now, his ideas about rocket propulsion will help us create a petrol station on the Moon.

title.children: Robert Goddard's ideas were mocked a century ago. Now, his ideas will help build a petrol station on the Moon

image.altText: Players react as the ball rolls through the goalposts

items.synopsis: Carlton are through to a preliminary final, but the final result and two-point margin only tell half the story on a remarkable night. Here are five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits — A Sam Walsh masterclass, a Max Gawn blunder and the play that rocked the MCG

image.altText: A netball team photo, one row of women is standing and another is kneeling in front. They wear the same uniform and smile.

items.synopsis: After being on the brink of fading away, a rural netball team in a tiny Victorian town has re-built and is showing just what they're capable of.

title.children: Tears, champagne and relief after rural netball team breaks years-long drought

image.altText: Toula from My Big Fat Greek Wedding sits at a table with her husband smiling at him, the ocean behind them

items.synopsis: When My Big Fat Greek Wedding came out more than 20 years ago, it made me feel seen as a member of the Greek diaspora. The third film isn't quite so impactful, but I still see myself in the story.

title.children: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3 may be cheesy, but it captures the joy of second-generation migrants going 'home'

image.altText: Two women take a selfie in front of a statue of a woman with snakes for hair

items.synopsis: Many mythical female monsters were created to scare women and children into submission. Today they could have a very different meaning.

title.children: These mythical females gifted babies and defied ideas of what women should be. They also ate people alive

image.altText: A cast of actors dressed in 70s clothing sing and dance on a blue-lit stage. In the centre is Gough Whitlam holding up a beer.

items.synopsis: Australia's great constitutional crisis of 1975 has all the right ingredients for a musical: high stakes, flawed characters and Norman Gunston. Meet the Australian writers bringing politics to the stage.

title.children: Australia's biggest political drama just got a musical theatre treatment to rival Hamilton

image.altText: A Matildas player during a Women's World Cup match against England in Sydney.

items.synopsis: In the wake of the Matildas' inspiring World Cup performance, defender Clare Hunt caps off her rapid rise by signing with French powerhouse Paris Saint-Germain.

title.children: Matildas star signs with European heavyweights after outstanding World Cup campaign

image.altText: An Australia batter looks frustrated after being dismissed in a men's ODI against South Africa.

items.synopsis: Travis Head suffers a fractured hand in a potential World Cup calamity for Australia amid a horror 164-run one-day hammering by South Africa in Centurion.

title.children: Head breaks hand in Australia's horror ODI loss to South Africa

image.altText: Will Warbrick catches a ball over Junior Pauga

items.synopsis: Will Warbrick caps a stellar rookie NRL season with a stunning try to win the Melbourne Storm's semifinal against the Roosters, and it was all part of the plan.

title.children: The high-flying, AFL-playing, Kiwi Olympian who saved the Melbourne Storm's NRL season

image.altText: Two men hugging at a presentation night

items.synopsis: Seven former players, including Phil Krakouer, launch a class action against the AFL for failing to protect players from racial abuse

title.children: 'Sorry doesn't cut it': Phil Krakouer leads racism class action against AFL

image.altText: A 1979 photo of a two-tier diving platform packed with people in board shorts and bikinis.

items.synopsis: One of the last remaining diving pools in Sydney is slated for closure, leaving only two publicly accessible diving facilities.

title.children: Diving platforms and springboards 'a thing of the past' as suburban pool-users trade fun for fitness

image.altText: RV Investigator in Antarctica

items.synopsis: As one scientist put it, humans "know more about the moon than we do about the deep ocean", but this ship — and those on board —have just chalked up their 100th mission, attempting to redress the knowledge imbalance.

title.children: 100 missions down, more to go for Australia's science ship RV Investigator

image.altText: Indigenous woman wearing an orange top with her hand to her chest. A large bottle of water is behind her.

items.synopsis: First Nations health professionals and those living with chronic health issues say they are "disappointed" and "deeply saddened" following Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's claims First Nations Australians are not living with ongoing negative impacts of colonisation.

title.children: First Nations health professionals 'deeply saddened' following senator's colonisation claims

image.altText: A small demon-like creature, the Knight, stands in a flowing blue cloak with a nail-like sword

items.synopsis: One of the most popular game development tools in the world announced new fees for using its service. It has left Australian game developers angry and perplexed — and could have ramifications for players, too.

title.children: 'Just devastating': Why your favourite video game creators are confused and furious right now

image.altText: Mural done in Brunswick by the Feminista Melbourne Collective of Mahsa Jina Amini who was killed in September 2022.

items.synopsis: As Iran's authoritarian regime has increased its brutality, its citizens have become more defiant — in Tehran's streets and in cyberspace. Iranians in the diaspora say the regime's days are numbered.

title.children: 'We are not the same people anymore': What's changed for Iranian women one year on from Mahsa Amini's death?

image.altText: A dual occupancy home with a white mailbox that has two openings that read "A" and "B".

items.synopsis: The ACT government is encouraging owners of big blocks to chop them up and build a second house, but recent history raises doubts about what that will achieve.

title.children: As Canberra grows, does 'gentle urbanism' offer the solution to a housing crisis?

image.altText: A candle being held by a pair of hands.

items.synopsis: WA's family violence statistics remain alarming, despite a reduction in the murder rate. State political reporter Keane Bourke looks at whether a new multi-agency approach can really make a difference.

title.children: We're still failing victims of domestic violence, and Western Australia is lagging far behind

image.altText: A man wearing a sunglasses looks to the side of the camera. Behind him is a housing development under construction

items.synopsis: In the wake of the collapse of three South Australian builders, the industry and the state government are reassuring a brighter future is ahead. But for those looking to find a builder, objective information is hard to come by.

title.children: Building trust: Consumers relying on word-of-mouth when making one of the biggest decisions of their lives

image.altText: Ange Postecoglou pumps his fist after Tottenham Hotspur defeats Bournemouth

items.synopsis: Ange Postecoglou's extraordinary impact at Tottenham has been marked by winning the first Premier League Manager of the Month award for the 2022/23 season.

title.children: Postecoglou's Spurs transformation recognised with Premier League award

image.altText: Servicemen sit in a tank with a flag of the Wagner Group military company.

items.synopsis: The United Kingdom officially proscribes the Russian mercenary Wagner Group as a terrorist organisation, after announcing the move last week.

title.children: UK officially proscribes Russia's Wagner as terrorist organisation

image.altText: A dingo standing on a rocky ledge looking out into the distance.

items.synopsis: Stuart Harradine says dingoes, or wilkerr as they are known in Weirgaia language, are a spiritual relation to his community and need to be looked at as more than a pest.

title.children: Totem species not wild dogs, says First Nations man seeking change to dingo management

image.altText: jeff stands in suncorp stadium holding boxing gloves with his hands up in the air

items.synopsis: Jeff Horn's journey from a timid, bullied teenager to an international lord of the boxing ring reads like the script of a feel-good blockbuster movie.

title.children: Six years after the height of Jeff Horn's fame, he says boxing is behind him and he couldn't be happier

image.altText: a composite image of the crime and corruption commission logo and queensland parliament

items.synopsis: This decision has been described as ''judgement day for integrity in Queensland" by the state opposition because of the implications for the Queensland Crime and Corruption Commission.

title.children: Why a High Court ruling has delivered a staggering blow to transparency and openness in Queensland

image.altText: Craypots and a small boat at a water's edge, with a hill and lighthouse in background against a setting evening's sky.

items.synopsis: Living on King Island off the coast of Tasmania comes with its trade-offs, as locals wait 12 months to see a physio and volunteer ambulance officers say call-outs to care for their community have resulted in PTSD.

title.children: In an island community this small, ambulance call-outs can mean finding your friends
